story:
Recent Patient testimonial: “...I am just so thankful that the vaccine has kept me going and I just hope that it’s more available to other people to save their lives. It is a godsend...” (16 year + disease-free survival)

Our vaccination therapy is quick to produce and safe to administer to a patient. A small sample of the patient’s tumor is taken by a physician and sent to our laboratory. Here we manufacture the vaccine by combining the patient’s tumor cell material with a powerful human immune stimulator Interleukin 2 (IL-2), to create billions of individual slow release Aggregon™ particles. These particles, when injected by the physician back into the patient from whom the tumor was extracted, will directly stimulate their immune system to recognize and attack their specific tumor cells.

A patient’s immune system tends to ignore cancer cells because they are made mostly of self-proteins. However, in the process of becoming malignant, cancer cells acquire mutated parts foreign enough that we can use them as a target for attack by our therapeutic vaccine.

The use of IL-2 to stimulate an anti-tumor immune response has been an FDA approved cancer therapy for years. However, when IL-2 alone is injected into the body it is eliminated quickly, which requires the use of very high toxic doses to be effective.

Our AggregonTM technology allows us to deliver the benefits of IL-2 in a personalized vaccine containing material from the patient’s own cancer cells in a non-toxic formulation. This formulation gently educates the patient’s immune system to identify and attack their cancer cells everywhere throughout their body.

Working in our manufacturing facility

Our cancer vaccine has already indicated efficacy in harnessing the immune system to combat cancer in two previous phase one clinical trials. These trials were performed at the National Cancer Institute in patients with Follicular Lymphoma. The vaccine showed no significant toxicity and the long-term benefits were very encouraging.

 


 A XEME scientist working in the clean room cancer vaccine manufacturing facility in Lombard, IL

 

The following graph represents the results of one of our first clinical trial in Lymphoma. Here, patients were first administered standard chemotherapy followed by a period of recovery for the immune system. These patients were then vaccinated with our non-toxic, personalized therapeutic vaccine. The data suggests that, for most patients, their immune system helped to keep them cancer free much longer than the expected relapse time after chemotherapy alone (orange vertical bars in the figure below). This encouraging data has inspired us to continue to gather more evidence to prove the effectiveness of our immunotherapy even in patients with a weakened immune systems.

Abbreviations: PR – Partial response; CCR – Continuous complete remission; PD – Progressive disease. See http://www.xemebiopharma.com for more details.

We are currently engaged in an ongoing clinical trial in patients with Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia (CLL) at Northwestern University in Chicago. For many patients CLL is a slow progressing cancer and patients often do not suffer from any symptoms of their disease until it is very advanced. Current therapies for CLL have toxic side effects. As a result, the standard of care is to "watch and wait", and start the treatment only when the patient becomes symptomatic.

XEME’s quality control lab in Lombard, IL

Our treatment is so gentle that we have been allowed to treat asymptomatic patients with CLL. Our goal is to postpone, as long as possible or even indefinitely, the progression of their disease and the need for more aggressive therapies. This is considered  by the FDA a “first in human” trial for CLL.

Loading vaccine samples in a high pressure liquid chromatography instrument

If successful, our new anti-cancer vaccine could improve the quality of life for many people and become the new standard of care. We plan to extend our research to follicular lymphoma and other forms of cancers in order to help as many patients as we can.

As you would expect, clinical trials are very expensive, and we have nearly exhausted our limited resources to reach this advanced clinical stage. Therefore, your help is critical to continue our clinical trials. Please help us in our endeavor to offer patients our unique, safe and affordable therapy.

Perks

 

Frequently Asked Questions

Q: What is the difference between a therapeutic cancer vaccine and a regular flu vaccine?

A: A regular flu vaccine is a preventative vaccine (prophylactic), minimizing the chance of one getting the flu. A therapeutic vaccine, on the other hand, is used after onset of the disease (cancer in our case) and is used to treat the disease.

Q: What is a personalized cancer vaccine?
A: A personalized cancer vaccine is a therapeutic vaccine that is manufactured using the patient’s own tumor material and hence is specific (personalized) to the patient’s own cancer.

Q: What is the vaccine made of and is it natural?
A: Our therapeutic cancer vaccine is made up of three components: 1. Proteins from the patient’s own cancerous cells, 2. An immune system stimulating protein (called human Interleukin-2, that activates the cells of the immune system to fight cancer cells) and 3. An inactive pharmaceutical ingredient (a phosphate rich lipid). The first component is the only natural ingredient out of the three. 

Q: What is the active ingredient in the vaccine?
A: There are two active pharmaceutical ingredients in our vaccine, 1. Proteins from the patient’s own cancer cells and 2. The immune system stimulating protein, human Interleukin-2.

Q: What is the size of the tumor sample needed to make a vaccine?
A: This depends on how many cancer cells are present in the tissue. Typically, a tumor biopsy of 0.5 gram – 2 grams is sufficient for manufacturing the vaccine. In the case of Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia patients, a billion tumor cells are more than enough for vaccine manufacturing; this number is easy to obtain.

Q: Can you make a vaccine from a biopsy sample?
A: Yes, in most cases we can; Typically a tumor biopsy of 0.5 gram – 2 grams in more than sufficient for manufacturing the vaccine.

Q: How long does it take to make a vaccine?
A: One of the unique attributes of our vaccine is the rapid manufacturing process (around 9 hours). The vaccine is released to the Oncologist for sub-cutaneous injection into patients in 1-4 weeks, after completion of all quality control testing.

Q: Where is the vaccine made?
A: The vaccine is manufactured in an ISO-5 biosafety hood that is housed in an ISO-7 clean room at our site in Lombard, IL. Some images of our manufacturing facility are shown above.

Q: How much will a vaccine treatment cost?
A: We are very cognizant of the pricing pressures that the US healthcare system currently faces. The price is anticipated to be in the same range as long standing, approved therapies. 

Q: Can you make a vaccine from a frozen sample?
A: Yes, we can.

Q: What types of cancers has this been tried on?
A: In humans, this vaccine has been tested in Phase I (One) clinical trials in Follicular Lymphoma. We are currently testing our personalized vaccine in Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia patients and have an FDA-approved, active Phase II trial in Follicular Lymphoma. Additionally, we’ve tested this type of vaccine successfully in mouse models of melanomas. We are also currently testing one of our vaccines in a mouse model of Colorectal Cancer. 

Q: Is there a type of cancer this will not work for?
A: Typically therapeutic cancer vaccines have the best chance of success in early stage disease where the patient’s immune system is intact and uncompromised by the tumor, or in situations where the tumor bulk is minimal (e.g. after tumor removal/reduction by surgery or other treatments).

Q: What criteria do you need to be a candidate for this vaccine treatment?
A: Currently, we have a Phase I (One) clinical trial ongoing in asymptomatic Chronic lymphocytic leukemia patients at the Lurie comprehensive cancer center at Northwestern University, Chicago. Relevant details of inclusion criteria can be found on our clinicaltrials.gov page at - https://clinicaltrials.gov/ct2/show/NCT01976520.

Q: Can this vaccine work if the patient has a suppressed immune system after chemo?
A: Typically vaccines recruit the cells of the immune system to fight disease. So for optimal action, an intact immune system offers the best opportunity. However, our vaccine can be effective if the immune system is allowed to sufficiently recover after chemotherapy. 

Q: What are the side effects of the vaccine?
A: In our two previously completed clinical trials and our current ongoing trial (more than 25 patients), we have only seen minor side effects, like injection site redness, soreness and mild fever.

Q: How often are the vaccine shots given?
A: 5 injections (shots) are administered to the patient, the first 2 of which are administered 2 weeks apart and the last three are monthly.

Q: Can one have a vaccine prepared even after they had other treatments?
A: Yes, vaccines can be administered after tumor debulking surgery or chemo / radiotherapy.

Q: Can the vaccine be used instead of other treatments?
A: This is precisely what we are testing in our ongoing clinical trials.

Q: Can your vaccine be exported to be administered by a physician outside the US?
A: Yes, depending on the medical regulatory conditions in other countries.

Q: When is the best time to get vaccinated?
A: Typically therapeutic cancer vaccines have the best chance of success in early stage disease where the patient’s immune system is intact and uncompromised by the tumor, or in situations where the tumor bulk is minimal (e.g. after tumor removal/reduction by surgery and before starting chemotherapy).

Q: Can a patient be vaccinated even if they have no symptoms?
A: Yes. Currently, we have an ongoing Phase I (One) clinical trial in asymptomatic Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia patients at the Lurie comprehensive cancer center at Northwestern University, Chicago.

Q: Can a patient have a vaccine treatment again if a tumor returns?
A: Our hope and expectation is that the vaccine will prevent cancer relapse. But in the situation that the cancer does come back, we have two choices – repeat injections with the vaccine made earlier for the patient (our vaccine has a shelf life of over 2 years when stored at -80°C) or use the metastatic tumor to manufacture a new vaccine.

Q: When do you expect to publish the result of this trial?
A: Since patients are followed for a period of up to 24 months post-vaccination, we anticipate publishing the data from this trial in 2.5-3 years time. This time frame will also answer the question whether our vaccine slows down progression of the disease and helps keep the patients asymptomatic for longer periods than is typically expected.

Q: How long have you been working on this project?
A: The principals have been involved in this field of research for the last 25 + years.
 
Q: How many employees do you currently have?
A: 5 full time and 5 part-time employees, plus outside technical support organizations.
 
Q: Why aren’t the big pharmaceutical companies making this vaccine?
A: Big pharmaceutical companies are mostly interested in standardized “off the shelf” products. A few relatively small companies have already started to experiment with various forms of personalized cancer vaccines. We believe that our vaccine, with its unique safety profile and speed of production has a best chance of success in some forms of cancer. 

Q: What types of cancers has this been tried on?
A: In humans, this vaccine has been tested in Phase I (One) clinical trials in Follicular Lymphoma. We are currently testing our personalized vaccine in Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia patients and have an FDA-approved, active Phase II trial in Follicular Lymphoma. Additionally, we've tested this type of vaccine successfully in mouse models of melanoma. We are also currently testing one of our vaccines in a mouse model of colorectal cancer. 

Q: Is there a type of cancer this will not work for?
A: Typically therapeutic cancer vaccines have the best chance of success in early stage disease where the patient's immune system is intact and uncompromised by the tumor, or in situations where the tumor bulk is minimal (e.g. after tumor removal/reduction by surgery or other treatments).

Q: What criteria do you need to be a candidate for this vaccine treatment?
A: Currently, we have a Phase I (One) clinical trial ongoing in asymptomatic Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia patients at the Lurie comprehensive cancer center at Northwestern University, Chicago. Relevant details of inclusion criteria can be found on our clinicaltrials.gov page at - https://clinicaltrials.gov/ct2/show/NCT01976520.

Q: Can this vaccine work if the patient has a suppressed immune system after chemo?
A: Typically vaccines recruit the cells of the immune system to fight disease. So, for optimal action, an intact immune system offers the best opportunity. However, our vaccine can be effective if the immune system is allowed to sufficiently recover after chemotherapy. 

Q: What are the side effects of the vaccine?
A: In our two previously completed clinical trials and our current ongoing trial (more than 25 patients), we have only seen minor side effects, like injection site redness, soreness and mild fever.

Q: How often are the vaccine shots given?
A: 5 injections (shots) are administered to the patient, the first 2 of which are administered 2 weeks apart and the last three are monthly.

Q: Can one have a vaccine done even after they had other treatments?
A: Yes, vaccines can be administered after tumor debulking surgery or chemo / radiotherapy.

Q: Can the vaccine be used instead of other treatments?
A: This is precisely what we are testing in our ongoing clinical trials.

Q: Can your vaccine be exported to be administered by a physician outside the US?
A: Yes, depending on the medical regulatory conditions in other countries.

Q: When is the best time to get vaccinated?
A: Typically, therapeutic cancer vaccines have the best chance of success in early stage disease when the patient's immune system is intact and uncompromised by the tumor, or in situations where the tumor bulk is minimal (e.g. after tumor removal/reduction by surgery and before starting chemotherapy).

XEME Management

Mircea Popescu, MD, PhD
Founder, President and CEO, Member of the Board

Mircea Popescu is a seasoned biopharma executive having previous direct responsibilities for managing corporate growth, fostering numerous product development collaborations with companies in the United States and elsewhere and supervising clinical trials. He was previously General Manager of Biomira USA where he initiated a productive collaboration on cancer vaccines with NCI/NIH, and was President of Oncotherapeutics where he was instrumental in completing one of the first international biotechnology merger transactions (with Biomira of Canada). Dr. Popescu was also a Research Fellow at Wyeth Vaccines, where he developed a novel flu vaccine that was tested in volunteers. He was Scientific Founder and Executive Director of The Liposome Company, one of the premier biotechnology concerns, where he focused on the development of company’s first therapeutic product that reached the market (ABELCET). Dr. Popescu has numerous publications in peer reviewed science journals and is a named inventor on 24 US patents including those supporting XEME’s technology platform.

 

Richard Robb, PhD
Founder, Vice President Research, Development and Quality Assurance

Richard Robb, PhD has held a variety of senior managerial positions for Research and Development at large pharmaceutical and biotechnology companies. He has an extensive science managerial experience that comprises pre-clinical research, product development, toxicology studies, quality control /assurance and organization and monitoring of clinical research. He gained international recognition for his work on Interleukin-2, one of the active ingredients in XEME’s therapeutic vaccines. The international standard for IL-2 quantification is based on his work. Dr. Robb manufactured the first biotechnology-derived IL-2 for use in clinical trials at the National Cancer Institute, a historic event for biotechnology industry. He has published over 80 scientific articles in prestigious journals, reviews and book chapters, was co-inventor on issued US patents and Principal Investigator on National Cancer Institute grants.

 

Larry Kwak, MD, PhD
Founder, Chairman Scientific Advisory Board, Clinical Research Consultant

Larry Kwak, MD, PhD was until recently the Chairman of the Department of Lymphoma and Myeloma and Co-Director of the Center for Cancer Immunology Research at the M.D. Anderson Cancer Center in Houston, Texas, where he also held the Justin Distinguished Chair in Leukemia Research. Since April 2015, Professor Kwak has served as Director, Toni Stephenson Lymphoma Center and Professor, Department of Hematology and Hematopoietic cell transplantation at City of Hope (www.cityofhope.org/faculty/larry-w.-kwak). Dr. Kwak previously served as Head of the Vaccine Biology Section at the NCI for 12 years. His NCI laboratory is credited with the bench-to-clinic development of a therapeutic cancer vaccine for B-cell malignancies, which was recently reported as positive in a landmark national Phase III clinical trial. He has authored more than 160 articles, which have been published in journals such as Science, Lancet, New England Journal of Medicine, and Nature Medicine. In 2010 Dr. Kwak was named to the TIME100, one of the world’s 100 most influential people by TIME magazine, for his 20 year commitment to the science of cancer vaccines. Dr. Kwak was awarded the Ho-Am prize in Medicine, Korea’s highest honor, for his work in immunotherapy in June 2016. Awarded since 1991, the Ho-Am is funded by the Korean company Samsung and is considered akin to Nobel Prize recognition.

 

Sunil Metkar, PhD, MBA
Chief Operating Officer

Sunil S. Metkar, PhD, MBA has several years of Life Science Venture Capital, Business Development and Competitive Intelligence experience. Dr. Metkar’s PhD thesis focused on Tumor Immunology in reference to hematological malignancies. He completed his post-doctoral fellowship at Northwestern University Feinberg School of Medicine, where he was also Assistant Professor (Research) in the Department of Medicine. Dr. Metkar earned his MBA from the Kellogg School of Management, majoring in Biotechnology, Strategy, Marketing and Entrepreneurship. He has worked with several startup companies in the therapeutic and diagnostics space.

 

Anthony Tate
Executive Vice President, Corporate Development

Anthony Tate has over 25 years of experience in sales, marketing and strategic business development for several bio-diagnostic and pharmaceutical companies; including several startup ventures. He helped found and has served as Vice President of sales and marketing for TheraTest Labs, was President and CEO of Norzyme (bio-therapeutic startup) and Director of Worldwide Sales and Marketing for ICN Pharmaceuticals, holding full profit and loss (P&L) responsibility for the its $100 Million bio-diagnostic division. He is also a veteran of the United States Marine Corps.

 

Marius Teodorescu, MD, PhD
Chairman of the Board

Marius Teodorescu, MD, PhD has direct experience in manufacture of viral vaccines and as a Professor at the University of Illinois (UIC) College of Medicine taught immunology to medical students, graduate students and physicians. Dr. Teodorescu also practiced rheumatology at the UIC College of Medicine for 25 years. He has more than 100 publications of original work, inventions, review articles and books chapters in immunology, rheumatology and related fields. In 1988, he founded TheraTest Laboratories Inc., a leading manufacturer and distributor of immunoassay test kits for rheumatology.

 

Mihai Teodorescu
Board Treasurer

Mihai Teodorescu is the President and COO of TheraTest Laboratories Inc. He worked in immunoassay test development and was instrumental in the development and corporate growth of TheraTest since its beginning. He has extensive experience in all aspects of the day-to-day operational activity of the Company’s FDA licensed manufacturing facility. He is also involved in the financial management and Human Resources activities at TheraTest and XEME.

 

Corina Dima, MS
Board Secretary

Corina Dima, M.S. is the VP for Quality Assurance of TheraTest Laboratories Inc., a position she has held for the past 15 years, and an essential member of the management team for about 20 years. A knowledgeable biochemist, she has unique organizational skills that have been essential in the successful performance of her multiple functions as quality assurance/quality control officer, reference laboratory manager and personnel development manager.

 

Dorel Nasui, MSCS, PhD
Member of Board of Directors

Dorel Nasui, MSCS, PhD is the CEO of American International Radio, Inc. and the Chairman of Safemobile LLC. He worked in IT and communications R&D and in 1990 founded American International Radio, Inc., an international system integrator and radio communication distributor, one of the largest Motorola Solutions distributors in the world with offices in 10 countries and partners in over 60. In 2001, he founded Safemobile LLC, a developer and a manufacturer of integrated GPS solutions, with applications in public safety and in various industries.

For more information, please visit our website at www.xemebiopharma.com
story_txt: Recent Patient testimonial: “...I am just so thankful that the vaccine has kept me going and I just hope that it’s more available to other people to save their lives. It is a godsend...” (16 year + disease-free survival)Our vaccination therapy is quick to produce and safe to administer to a patient. A small sample of the patient’s tumor is taken by a physician and sent to our laboratory. Here we manufacture the vaccine by combining the patient’s tumor cell material with a powerful human immune stimulator Interleukin 2 (IL-2), to create billions of individual slow release Aggregon™ particles. These particles, when injected by the physician back into the patient from whom the tumor was extracted, will directly stimulate their immune system to recognize and attack their specific tumor cells.A patient’s immune system tends to ignore cancer cells because they are made mostly of self-proteins. However, in the process of becoming malignant, cancer cells acquire mutated parts foreign enough that we can use them as a target for attack by our therapeutic vaccine.The use of IL-2 to stimulate an anti-tumor immune response has been an FDA approved cancer therapy for years. However, when IL-2 alone is injected into the body it is eliminated quickly, which requires the use of very high toxic doses to be effective.Our AggregonTM technology allows us to deliver the benefits of IL-2 in a personalized vaccine containing material from the patient’s own cancer cells in a non-toxic formulation. This formulation gently educates the patient’s immune system to identify and attack their cancer cells everywhere throughout their body.Working in our manufacturing facilityOur cancer vaccine has already indicated efficacy in harnessing the immune system to combat cancer in two previous phase one clinical trials. These trials were performed at the National Cancer Institute in patients with Follicular Lymphoma. The vaccine showed no significant toxicity and the long-term benefits were very encouraging.  A XEME scientist working in the clean room cancer vaccine manufacturing facility in Lombard, IL The following graph represents the results of one of our first clinical trial in Lymphoma. Here, patients were first administered standard chemotherapy followed by a period of recovery for the immune system. These patients were then vaccinated with our non-toxic, personalized therapeutic vaccine. The data suggests that, for most patients, their immune system helped to keep them cancer free much longer than the expected relapse time after chemotherapy alone (orange vertical bars in the figure below). This encouraging data has inspired us to continue to gather more evidence to prove the effectiveness of our immunotherapy even in patients with a weakened immune systems.Abbreviations: PR – Partial response; CCR – Continuous complete remission; PD – Progressive disease. See http://www.xemebiopharma.com for more details.We are currently engaged in an ongoing clinical trial in patients with Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia (CLL) at Northwestern University in Chicago. For many patients CLL is a slow progressing cancer and patients often do not suffer from any symptoms of their disease until it is very advanced. Current therapies for CLL have toxic side effects. As a result, the standard of care is to "watch and wait", and start the treatment only when the patient becomes symptomatic.XEME’s quality control lab in Lombard, ILOur treatment is so gentle that we have been allowed to treat asymptomatic patients with CLL. Our goal is to postpone, as long as possible or even indefinitely, the progression of their disease and the need for more aggressive therapies. This is considered  by the FDA a “first in human” trial for CLL.Loading vaccine samples in a high pressure liquid chromatography instrumentIf successful, our new anti-cancer vaccine could improve the quality of life for many people and become the new standard of care. We plan to extend our research to follicular lymphoma and other forms of cancers in order to help as many patients as we can.As you would expect, clinical trials are very expensive, and we have nearly exhausted our limited resources to reach this advanced clinical stage. Therefore, your help is critical to continue our clinical trials. Please help us in our endeavor to offer patients our unique, safe and affordable therapy.Perks Frequently Asked QuestionsQ: What is the difference between a therapeutic cancer vaccine and a regular flu vaccine?A: A regular flu vaccine is a preventative vaccine (prophylactic), minimizing the chance of one getting the flu. A therapeutic vaccine, on the other hand, is used after onset of the disease (cancer in our case) and is used to treat the disease.Q: What is a personalized cancer vaccine?A: A personalized cancer vaccine is a therapeutic vaccine that is manufactured using the patient’s own tumor material and hence is specific (personalized) to the patient’s own cancer.Q: What is the vaccine made of and is it natural?A: Our therapeutic cancer vaccine is made up of three components: 1. Proteins from the patient’s own cancerous cells, 2. An immune system stimulating protein (called human Interleukin-2, that activates the cells of the immune system to fight cancer cells) and 3. An inactive pharmaceutical ingredient (a phosphate rich lipid). The first component is the only natural ingredient out of the three. Q: What is the active ingredient in the vaccine?A: There are two active pharmaceutical ingredients in our vaccine, 1. Proteins from the patient’s own cancer cells and 2. The immune system stimulating protein, human Interleukin-2.Q: What is the size of the tumor sample needed to make a vaccine?A: This depends on how many cancer cells are present in the tissue. Typically, a tumor biopsy of 0.5 gram – 2 grams is sufficient for manufacturing the vaccine. In the case of Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia patients, a billion tumor cells are more than enough for vaccine manufacturing; this number is easy to obtain.Q: Can you make a vaccine from a biopsy sample?A: Yes, in most cases we can; Typically a tumor biopsy of 0.5 gram – 2 grams in more than sufficient for manufacturing the vaccine.Q: How long does it take to make a vaccine?A: One of the unique attributes of our vaccine is the rapid manufacturing process (around 9 hours). The vaccine is released to the Oncologist for sub-cutaneous injection into patients in 1-4 weeks, after completion of all quality control testing.Q: Where is the vaccine made?A: The vaccine is manufactured in an ISO-5 biosafety hood that is housed in an ISO-7 clean room at our site in Lombard, IL. Some images of our manufacturing facility are shown above.Q: How much will a vaccine treatment cost?A: We are very cognizant of the pricing pressures that the US healthcare system currently faces. The price is anticipated to be in the same range as long standing, approved therapies. Q: Can you make a vaccine from a frozen sample?A: Yes, we can.Q: What types of cancers has this been tried on?A: In humans, this vaccine has been tested in Phase I (One) clinical trials in Follicular Lymphoma. We are currently testing our personalized vaccine in Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia patients and have an FDA-approved, active Phase II trial in Follicular Lymphoma. Additionally, we’ve tested this type of vaccine successfully in mouse models of melanomas. We are also currently testing one of our vaccines in a mouse model of Colorectal Cancer. Q: Is there a type of cancer this will not work for?A: Typically therapeutic cancer vaccines have the best chance of success in early stage disease where the patient’s immune system is intact and uncompromised by the tumor, or in situations where the tumor bulk is minimal (e.g. after tumor removal/reduction by surgery or other treatments).Q: What criteria do you need to be a candidate for this vaccine treatment?A: Currently, we have a Phase I (One) clinical trial ongoing in asymptomatic Chronic lymphocytic leukemia patients at the Lurie comprehensive cancer center at Northwestern University, Chicago. Relevant details of inclusion criteria can be found on our clinicaltrials.gov page at - https://clinicaltrials.gov/ct2/show/NCT01976520.Q: Can this vaccine work if the patient has a suppressed immune system after chemo?A: Typically vaccines recruit the cells of the immune system to fight disease. So for optimal action, an intact immune system offers the best opportunity. However, our vaccine can be effective if the immune system is allowed to sufficiently recover after chemotherapy. Q: What are the side effects of the vaccine?A: In our two previously completed clinical trials and our current ongoing trial (more than 25 patients), we have only seen minor side effects, like injection site redness, soreness and mild fever.Q: How often are the vaccine shots given?A: 5 injections (shots) are administered to the patient, the first 2 of which are administered 2 weeks apart and the last three are monthly.Q: Can one have a vaccine prepared even after they had other treatments?A: Yes, vaccines can be administered after tumor debulking surgery or chemo / radiotherapy.Q: Can the vaccine be used instead of other treatments?A: This is precisely what we are testing in our ongoing clinical trials.Q: Can your vaccine be exported to be administered by a physician outside the US?A: Yes, depending on the medical regulatory conditions in other countries.Q: When is the best time to get vaccinated?A: Typically therapeutic cancer vaccines have the best chance of success in early stage disease where the patient’s immune system is intact and uncompromised by the tumor, or in situations where the tumor bulk is minimal (e.g. after tumor removal/reduction by surgery and before starting chemotherapy).Q: Can a patient be vaccinated even if they have no symptoms?A: Yes. Currently, we have an ongoing Phase I (One) clinical trial in asymptomatic Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia patients at the Lurie comprehensive cancer center at Northwestern University, Chicago.Q: Can a patient have a vaccine treatment again if a tumor returns?A: Our hope and expectation is that the vaccine will prevent cancer relapse. But in the situation that the cancer does come back, we have two choices – repeat injections with the vaccine made earlier for the patient (our vaccine has a shelf life of over 2 years when stored at -80°C) or use the metastatic tumor to manufacture a new vaccine.Q: When do you expect to publish the result of this trial?A: Since patients are followed for a period of up to 24 months post-vaccination, we anticipate publishing the data from this trial in 2.5-3 years time. This time frame will also answer the question whether our vaccine slows down progression of the disease and helps keep the patients asymptomatic for longer periods than is typically expected.Q: How long have you been working on this project?A: The principals have been involved in this field of research for the last 25 + years. Q: How many employees do you currently have?A: 5 full time and 5 part-time employees, plus outside technical support organizations. Q: Why aren’t the big pharmaceutical companies making this vaccine?A: Big pharmaceutical companies are mostly interested in standardized “off the shelf” products. A few relatively small companies have already started to experiment with various forms of personalized cancer vaccines. We believe that our vaccine, with its unique safety profile and speed of production has a best chance of success in some forms of cancer. Q: What types of cancers has this been tried on?A: In humans, this vaccine has been tested in Phase I (One) clinical trials in Follicular Lymphoma. We are currently testing our personalized vaccine in Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia patients and have an FDA-approved, active Phase II trial in Follicular Lymphoma. Additionally, we've tested this type of vaccine successfully in mouse models of melanoma. We are also currently testing one of our vaccines in a mouse model of colorectal cancer. Q: Is there a type of cancer this will not work for?A: Typically therapeutic cancer vaccines have the best chance of success in early stage disease where the patient's immune system is intact and uncompromised by the tumor, or in situations where the tumor bulk is minimal (e.g. after tumor removal/reduction by surgery or other treatments).Q: What criteria do you need to be a candidate for this vaccine treatment?A: Currently, we have a Phase I (One) clinical trial ongoing in asymptomatic Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia patients at the Lurie comprehensive cancer center at Northwestern University, Chicago. Relevant details of inclusion criteria can be found on our clinicaltrials.gov page at - https://clinicaltrials.gov/ct2/show/NCT01976520.Q: Can this vaccine work if the patient has a suppressed immune system after chemo?A: Typically vaccines recruit the cells of the immune system to fight disease. So, for optimal action, an intact immune system offers the best opportunity. However, our vaccine can be effective if the immune system is allowed to sufficiently recover after chemotherapy. Q: What are the side effects of the vaccine?A: In our two previously completed clinical trials and our current ongoing trial (more than 25 patients), we have only seen minor side effects, like injection site redness, soreness and mild fever.Q: How often are the vaccine shots given?A: 5 injections (shots) are administered to the patient, the first 2 of which are administered 2 weeks apart and the last three are monthly.Q: Can one have a vaccine done even after they had other treatments?A: Yes, vaccines can be administered after tumor debulking surgery or chemo / radiotherapy.Q: Can the vaccine be used instead of other treatments?A: This is precisely what we are testing in our ongoing clinical trials.Q: Can your vaccine be exported to be administered by a physician outside the US?A: Yes, depending on the medical regulatory conditions in other countries.Q: When is the best time to get vaccinated?A: Typically, therapeutic cancer vaccines have the best chance of success in early stage disease when the patient's immune system is intact and uncompromised by the tumor, or in situations where the tumor bulk is minimal (e.g. after tumor removal/reduction by surgery and before starting chemotherapy).XEME ManagementMircea Popescu, MD, PhDFounder, President and CEO, Member of the BoardMircea Popescu is a seasoned biopharma executive having previous direct responsibilities for managing corporate growth, fostering numerous product development collaborations with companies in the United States and elsewhere and supervising clinical trials. He was previously General Manager of Biomira USA where he initiated a productive collaboration on cancer vaccines with NCI/NIH, and was President of Oncotherapeutics where he was instrumental in completing one of the first international biotechnology merger transactions (with Biomira of Canada). Dr. Popescu was also a Research Fellow at Wyeth Vaccines, where he developed a novel flu vaccine that was tested in volunteers. He was Scientific Founder and Executive Director of The Liposome Company, one of the premier biotechnology concerns, where he focused on the development of company’s first therapeutic product that reached the market (ABELCET). Dr. Popescu has numerous publications in peer reviewed science journals and is a named inventor on 24 US patents including those supporting XEME’s technology platform. Richard Robb, PhDFounder, Vice President Research, Development and Quality AssuranceRichard Robb, PhD has held a variety of senior managerial positions for Research and Development at large pharmaceutical and biotechnology companies. He has an extensive science managerial experience that comprises pre-clinical research, product development, toxicology studies, quality control /assurance and organization and monitoring of clinical research. He gained international recognition for his work on Interleukin-2, one of the active ingredients in XEME’s therapeutic vaccines. The international standard for IL-2 quantification is based on his work. Dr. Robb manufactured the first biotechnology-derived IL-2 for use in clinical trials at the National Cancer Institute, a historic event for biotechnology industry. He has published over 80 scientific articles in prestigious journals, reviews and book chapters, was co-inventor on issued US patents and Principal Investigator on National Cancer Institute grants. Larry Kwak, MD, PhDFounder, Chairman Scientific Advisory Board, Clinical Research ConsultantLarry Kwak, MD, PhD was until recently the Chairman of the Department of Lymphoma and Myeloma and Co-Director of the Center for Cancer Immunology Research at the M.D. Anderson Cancer Center in Houston, Texas, where he also held the Justin Distinguished Chair in Leukemia Research. story:
Who We Are

We at Gifford Fitness are here to inspire people to be better. Better athletes, family members, friends, coworkers, and better people. We do this by promoting a constant pursuit of excellence. We are committed to our clients’ growth and their goals. We aim to be leaders in our industry, and we aim for our clients to be leaders in our society.

This campaign was started to fund this project and to help provide the walls and the tools needed to build a community in the North Metro, opening Summer 2016.

Our Campaign Goals

  • $10,000- This will outfit our new gym with the bare essentials, including bars, weights, flooring, paint, a pullup rig, medicine balls, materials to make our own plyo boxes, jump ropes, etc.
  • $15,000- Sanctioning fees for CrossFit affiliation and USA Weightlifting club membership.
  • $18,000- Supplemental equipment such as rowers, kettle bells, dumbbells, etc.
  • $20,000- Members lounge, retail area, etc.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are not able to help out monetarily, there are still ways to contribute! You can:

  • Share this post on your social media
  • Follow Gifford Fitness on Facebook and Instagram
  • If you have items that you are willing to donate to our members' lounge or retail area, please email nick@giffordfitness.com
Thank you for all your help and support!

story:
Background
My name is Nathan a Fox and I am a current ENG/GB International Triple Jumper aiming to fulfil my dream of competing at the Rio 2016 Olympics. I have been in the sport since 2003 and have experienced a tremendous about of highs and lows along the way. Now at the age of 25, I truly believe that I am ready to take my place amongst the world’s best and compete at the highest level. Currently I am 16cms (Yes 16!) away from qualifying for the Olympic Games and I am fully confident of achieving that this in the summer. The next 4 years are crucial and I have the ability to be able to medal at the 2020 Olympic Games in Tokyo.

Current Situation
At Present, I am entirely self-funded and work as much as I can in order to finance my sport. This itself is a 'catch 22' as the more time I spend away from the track, the more I hamper my chances of reaching my full potential.  A badly timed injury in 2012 left me unable to apply for traditional funding from the usual sources such as the National Lottery and British Athletics, however, my recent performances and titles are sound evidence that I have the ability to bounce back from adversity. My training involves going to warmer climes at various points during the athletic calendar and I made a trip to South Africa In January (3 weeks) and one scheduled for Florida in April (6 weeks) which will cost £4,000 alone. When you add the training, travel costs, physiotherapy and equipment, my annual fees run to excess of £6,000, which I struggle to raise in a way that does not have a negative impact on my training schedule.

Your Help
Your donations will go an extremely long way in helping me achieve my goal of competing at the Olympics. Not only will it allow me to cover my expenses (travel, coaching fees, warm weather training, physiotherapy), it will also give me the much needed peace of mind to focus solely on training and compete on the world stage.  I want to thank you in advance for reading my story and an even bigger thank you for those that donate. See you in Rio!

Future Championships I Plan To Make In Next Two Years:
- 2016 Olympics (Brazil)
- 2017 European Indoor Championships (Serbia)
- 2017 World Championships (London)
- 2018 World Indoor Championships (Birmingham)
- 2018 Commonwealth Games (Gold Coast)

Below are a list of my most relevant achievements:
- Current UK under 15 All Time Record Holder
- Under 17 English Schools, AAA’s & UK School Games Champion (2007)
- 5th At European Youth Olympics 2007 (First Major International)
- 2007 BBC London Rising Male Sports Award
- Serious thigh Injury resulting in 12months out (2008)
- Three Times British University Champion (2010, 2011, 2013)
- 2012 Aviva Olympic Trials Bronze Medallist
- Torn Ankle Ligaments resulting in 6months out (2012)
- 2013 Sainsbury’s British Championships Bronze Medallist
- 2014 British Athletics Championships Silver Medallist
- 2014 6th Place @ Glasgow Commonwealth Games
- 2015 Sainsbury’s British Indoor Champion
- 2015 England Athletics Senior Champion
- 2016 British Indoor Champion

story:
Je me présente je m'appelle Alexandre j'ai 19ans suite à mauvais plongeon le 16 août 2015 sous un beau soleil d'été j'ai heurté le fond de l'eau qui m'a provoquer une fracture des cervicales C5-C6 qui m'a aussi touché la moelle épinière,  qui m'a rendu tétraplégique,  niveau neurologiques C7 une paralysie total des jambes et les mains ( les doigts).

Ainsi que :

-Des trouble moteurs 

- Des troubles sensitifs

- Des troubles shincteriens 

-Des troubles respiratoire 

-Des troubles vesicaux et intestinaux 

- Des troubles neurologiques 

Actuellement en centre de rééducation depuis septembre je me bât pour retrouver le plus d'autonomie pour la sortie car la je vie en fauteuil est très difficile point de vue déplacement et autre inconvénients ,et qui va me nécessité beaucoup d'aide pour le domicile et la vie quotidienne. Ainsi que pour améliorer les conditions de vie au maximum par rapport au handicap le matériel dont je vais avoir besoin ( fauteuils roulants,  fauteuils verticalisateur,matériel ergonomiques,  adapter voiture au handicap, équipements pour la rééducation etc..) tout au mieux qui peut me faciliter le quotidien mais cela a un coût d'une belle importantance  et pas tout est pris en charge à 100%. Mon accident c'est passé la veille de mon premier emploi .  Je fais donc appelle à vous pour m'aider face à cette situation. 

Je vous remercie d'avoir pris le temps de lire ma situation. 

Site sécurisé.  Pour toute information complémentaire 06.59.49.98.02
story_txt: Je me présente je m'appelle Alexandre j'ai 19ans suite à mauvais plongeon le 16 août 2015 sous un beau soleil d'été j'ai heurté le fond de l'eau qui m'a provoquer une fracture des cervicales C5-C6 qui m'a aussi touché la moelle épinière,  qui m'a rendu tétraplégique,  niveau neurologiques C7 une paralysie total des jambes et les mains ( les doigts).Ainsi que :-Des trouble moteurs - Des troubles sensitifs- Des troubles shincteriens -Des troubles respiratoire -Des troubles vesicaux et intestinaux - Des troubles neurologiques Actuellement en centre de rééducation depuis septembre je me bât pour retrouver le plus d'autonomie pour la sortie car la je vie en fauteuil est très difficile point de vue déplacement et autre inconvénients ,et qui va me nécessité beaucoup d'aide pour le domicile et la vie quotidienne. story:
Matching Gift Challenge EXTENDED!

Thanks to Stella Maris Foundation for supporting our $10,000 MATCHING GIFT CHALLENGE. Stella Maris Foundation has generously pledged to match donations dollar for dollar up to $10k! That means your donations is doubled in value.

Please note that due to Stella Maris Foundation's funding mechanism requirements ("old fashioned checks" in their words), we will not see their matching donations on the Indiegogo funding bar. We will track their matching donations on our main campaign page, so you can see that we're progressing towards $40,000 at double speed.

 

Compassionate use is how terminally and chronically ill patients can access experimental drugs when they want to fight to LIVE—when standard treatments haven’t worked and they can’t get into clinical trials.

Here’s the problem: Before patients can even ask for government approval for compassionate use, the drug company needs to say YES. Most patients hear NO.

We saw our friends’ families devastated by NO, denied the chance to fight to live. We started CURe (Compassionate Use Reform) to make compassionate use work for patients and their families.

We need your help to launch CURe’s two core programs::

INFO HUB—an online guide to help patients and families navigate the compassionate use process

SOLUTION HUB—CURe will collaborate with patients, drug companies, doctors, and government to build practical, win-win solutions to get drug companies to YES

This problem is solvable. Let’s solve it.
Help us raise the $40,000 to launch Info Hub.

How can CURe change lives? Gavin Pierson’s story shows us  just what compassionate use can mean to one little boy who is alive today and growing up against all odds. (watch the video!)

Right now, Gavin’s YES story is the exception. Let’s make that YES the usual story.
Join us with a $25 contribution. SAY YES.



 

Gavin’s story show how a compassionate use YES gives a family the hope to keep fighting and, in some cases, keeps a family whole. It also shines a light on how difficult it is right now for patients to get good information on compassionate use.

GAVIN VS. “JOE BULLY”
In 2012, doctors told Nicole and Steve Pierson that their five-year-old Gavin had a teratoma (tumor) in his brain. Standard treatment for growing teratoma syndrome included chemotherapy and surgically removing the tumor, but the doctors could not fully remove the tumor without fatal damage to Gavin’s brain. So, Gavin had craniotomy after craniotomy to remove as much of the tumor as possible and keep up with new growth.

Gavin named his tumor “Joe Bully” and told his family he and his doctors were going to beat Joe Bully.

A MOTHER TAKES ACTION
In the meantime, Nicole understood that the unending series of craniotomies would only extend Gavin’s life for so long—and that the damage and the recovery from each surgery was harder and harder for Gavin.

In her desperate nighttime research, she learned of an experimental drug by Pfizer was showing success in stopping teratoma growth in some adults. But Pfizer said that Gavin was too young to participate in the clinical trial. They said they might run a pediatric trial the next year. Everything Gavin endured thereafter was to keep him alive in hopes that he’d make it to that clinical trial.

THE WORST NEWS
At Christmas, Gavin’s tumor started growing very rapidly. Gavin only had a couple months to live. His doctors called Pfizer again, hoping the pediatric trial might be ready to go. The pediatric trial was too far off to help Gavin.

Only then did Gavin’s doctors and Pfizer raise compassionate use as an option, telling Nicole that compassionate use was a way to access experimental treatments when no standard treatment or clinical trial options remained. In the six months after they knew that standard care would not save Gavin, no one had ever told her about compassionate use.

COMPASSIONATE USE
Gavin was fortunate. Pfizer said YES and gave Gavin compassionate use of the experimental drug. Even more fortunate, the drug worked. It stopped the tumor growth, keeping Gavin stable until a new innovative laser was available to treat the rest of Joe Bully.

“WE WERE LUCKY, AND THAT SHOULDN’T BE”
Today, Gavin’s YES from a drug company is the exception.

And even so, these days Nicole talks to drug companies and to doctors to emphasize that they need to explain compassionate use (and other stages of investigational treatment access) to patients far earlier in the treatment process. In Gavin’s case, it was clear that standard care would not save Gavin’s life after his first craniotomy. She asks why she was not told of the possibility of compassionate use until six months and three more craniotomies?

Nicole’s message to drug companies: “I feel that we just fell upon it, and we are lucky. And that shouldn’t be. If you could just say, Yes, you can try this drug, and it might not cure you, but you can try it.”

Gavin was declared cancer-free in June, 2016.

To learn more about Gavin’s story: Gavin has an army of supporters on Facebook, and Nicole recently published a memoir of Gavin’s journey, “Be Strong and Brave.”

 

Patients face two problems when  seeking compassionate use: (1) a NO from the drug company and (2) little to no useful resources to help them ask the drug companies for compassionate use.

The government now has a solid compassionate use program, but before a patient can ask the government to approve compassionate use, the drug company first has to say “YES, we will allow compassionate use of our experimental drug.” Instead, patients usually receive a NO.

For patients and their doctors, getting the drug company to say YES feels like a hit-or-miss process of reaching the right executive at the right company at the right time for the right disease. AND THAT’S NOT RIGHT.

If that weren’t difficult enough, there are very few resources that explain to patients (and to doctors) how to request compassionate use. Even less information is out there about the hard, confusing, and often frustrating part: asking a drug company for compassionate use. The resources that do exist are not written or designed for patients and families who are sick, emotionally strained, tired, stressed, and critically pressed for time.

 

No one knows the number of patients seeking compassionate use from drug companies each year. The requests that receive “NO” from a drug company generally go unrecorded.

The U.S. FDA receives on average 1,210 requests each year and approved 99% of those requests. Unfortunately, FDA data tell us nothing about the actual number of people who asked drug companies and received a NO, because FDA does not accept formal requests until after a drug company says YES.

What we do know is that the number of people who ask drug companies for compassionate use is bigger—much bigger—than the number of drug company YES's effectively recorded by FDA.

 

 

#1— We’re starting with CURe INFO HUB. We need to deliver a patient-centric online guide, written and designed for the patients and families asking for compassionate use.

A Guide that...

  • is easy to read and understand for stressed out, sick, time-pressed, and exhausted patients and families
  • helps patients through the whole process—from first talking to a doctor to asking a drug company for compassionate use to seeking government approval
  • provides  info about people’s past experiences seeking compassionate use

We want to build a compassionate use guide FOR PATIENTS.
Your $25 contribution will get the INFO HUB guide off the ground.

 

 

#2—Next, we’ll launch CURe SOLUTION HUB: We’re going to work collaboratively to build practical, win-win solutions that work for patients and the drug companies.

There are some legitimate reasons why a drug company could say NO to compassionate use, and unfortunately there are also self-interested excuses used to deny potentially life-saving options to patients. We believe most of the barriers can be overcome. (see FAQs below for examples of reasons)

Solution Hub will bring together all the players—patient advocates, doctors, drug companies, and government—along with innovative thinkers outside the health world to generate fresh and practical ideas. For each barrier we identify, Solution Hub teams will harness the policy fixes, business models, and/or clinical research models appropriate to lowering the barrier to YES.

 

To make compassionate use work well for patients, we need to work well with all parties. So we’ve spent a lot of time during our first year talking to patients, drug companies (big and small), patient advocates (grassroots and well-established), doctors, policymakers, scholars and media experts who participate in the compassionate use discussion. We need the perspective of each stakeholder group, so we ask advice from all of them. Across the board they’ve given us positive encouragement, amazing and constructive feedback on our plans, and their own ideas for making compassionate use work better.

 

With a contribution to launch Info Hub, you will help patients and families find clear information and navigation guidance through the compassionate use process. In the video, you heard from Gavin’s mom that patients don’t get enough information on compassionate use. You can help fix that by:

  1. Giving $25 (the price of two movie tickets and some popcorn!)
  2. Sharing our campaign on Facebook and Twitter to keep the momentum alive!

After you help us meet our $40,000 goal, we’ll set a stretch goal to fund the launch of Solution Hub. And if we get our Generosity groove on full-throttle, we’ll reach for the stars and raise funds for a full year of CURe operations:

 

We at CURe firmly believe you should know how your contributions will be used to accomplish our goal. We provide below a budget breakdown for Info Hub’s launch. We are also registered with Guidestar to share CURe’s organizational information, including financials.

 

 

Karen Laughlin | co-founder & executive director

I am passionately convinced that there are practical win-win-win ways to make compassionate use work if we get creative and work together. I learned about compassionate use the hard way: fighting to get access to an experimental drug for my friend Nick Auden—husband of my very first friend in life, Amy, and dad to three little kids. Nick died hearing NO. I’ve taken the last year away from my “normal” career to get CURe off the ground and change that story for other families.

I bring to CURe regulatory experience, years of working across different stakeholder groups, and an ease with the science world. A biologist by training, I have worked on domestic regulation and negotiated for the U.S. Government as a senior policy advisor at the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency. I also jointly managed a think tank program to identify paths to lower cost barriers to clean energy. I live in San Francisco. In my spare time, I love surfing (or, rather, falling off surfboards).

 

Jim Walters | co-founder

I learned about the difficulties facing patients and their families when I was asked to help rally a Facebook community—Andi’s Army—to support Andrea Sloan’s search for compassionate use. During the campaign I witnessed the power of many to work together to create hope. Andrea got access to the drug she needed, but it came too late and from a different drug company than the one we begged for months. She immediately, while extremely sick herself, asked that I join her in helping support another patient, Nick Auden. I made a promise to Andrea to help make the process easier for everyone who wants to continue to fight to live. Her inspiration continues to guide me in working with this amazing team.

As a father of three, I want my children to see that we work not only for a living but to better the world around us for ourselves and for each other. In addition to providing support for CURe, I own and manage AHD Multimedia LLC, a company that specializes in video content creation, providing creative online marketing support for businesses and non-profit organizations. I live in Austin, Texas. In my spare time, I love training Jiu Jitsu with my wife and daughters, where we learn to solve life’s challenges with leverage and flow.

 

Mark Shilling | co-founder

Several years ago I introduced my friends Jim Walters and Andrea Sloan to work on a project to raise money for cancer research. I couldn’t have possibly imagined the path from there to here—or that it would result in the launch of CURe. Everyone I have met and worked with along the way has been such an inspiration in so many ways and I feel both lucky and humbled to be involved in such a great and laudable undertaking.

I help provide CURe direction on administrative and governance issues as well as advocacy and policy direction. My experience as a public affairs consultant and lobbyist have been extremely beneficial in helping create the foundation. In addition to my lobby practice, Shilling Public Affairs, I have also co-created Revolution Spirits, an Austin-based craft spirits distillery. I live in Austin with my wife and adorable mutts, and in my spare time, I long for the that day that I might actually have some spare time.

 

 

How does a patient get approval for compassionate use of experimental medical treatments?

Compassionate use in most countries requires 2-3 steps:

  1. Drug Company Agreement
    The drug company must determine if it will provide the experimental drug to the patient, because the drug company owns the drug. Drug companies are not obligated to provide compassionate use of drugs under development.
  2. Government Approval
  3. Medical Ethics Committee
    Some countries require that a medical ethics committee approve and monitor a compassionate use treatment plan to ensure that patient welfare is appropriately considered.

The requirements for government approval differ from country to country. See our Compassionate Use by Country for a summary of compassionate use approval programs in the United States, European Union, Canada, and Australia.

 

Why would drug companies say NO to compassionate use?

There are several reasons why drug companies deny compassionate use, depending on the company’s size, mission, culture, and precedent, on manufacturing limitations, and on clinical trial constraints. These barriers and disincentives can include:

  • Financial—Smaller companies, often the developers of cutting-edge treatments, might be cash strapped and unable to divert funds from clinical trials
  • Profit—Companies are not allowed to profit from compassionate use
  • Regulatory—Some companies are concerned that a harmful side effect in a compassionate use case may give government regulators reason to deny approval of the drug
  • Human Resources & In-House Knowledge—Some smaller companies do not know how to conduct compassionate use and/or cannot afford the additional staff to manage it
  • Manufacturing—Sometimes a drug company has challenges supplying its clinical trials with the drug and cannot spare drug supplies for compassionate use
  • Cultural—Some drug companies have not made the decision—yet—that  from the top-down their company will make compassionate use work for the patient when it is medically appropriate and logistically possible

We strongly believe that there are practical win-win solutions to lower or eliminate many of these barriers. Some solutions are already at our fingertips. Others can be built with a willingness to work together. CURe will make that work happen with Solution Hub.

 

Why would drug companies be interested in finding solutions to make compassionate use work?

First, drug companies are made up of people, many who want to help other people. Some drug company employees have fought doggedly inside their companies for compassionate use and have been deeply saddened and frustrated when their companies say no. There is a mountain of good will working within the drug development industry, and we want to leverage that for the good of patients and their families.

Second, social media and press spotlights have turned up the pressure on drug companies to improve their compassionate use records and to play a leading role in making compassionate use work for patients.

A few companies have taken notable steps to improve their compassionate use process. For example, in 2015 Johnson & Johnson announced that they would work with NYU School of Medicine to pilot an external committee to fairly determine which patients should receive compassionate use of a limited supply of one experimental drug. This year the company decided to expand the program to cover all of its experimental medical products. It’s a good start.

 

Is government the problem?

Our short answer: No.

In the U.S., FDA has a strong compassionate use program that is medically sensible, appropriate for the greater public good, and compassionate towards patients. But until drug companies improve their compassionate use participation, patients and doctors cannot use the FDA program to its full potential.

Government still has an important problem-solving role to play. To lower the barriers that drug companies face , we need government participation in building win-win solutions that will work in current and future regulatory environments.

 

Is it ethical to provide compassionate use to patients when the medical treatments are not fully tested and proven effective?

The ethics of compassionate use have been a serious discussion since the inception of compassionate use programs.

The big question is whether it is ethical to administer experimental drugs to patients before we know if the drugs are effective and before we understand the full set of risks associated with the drug. This article provides a good summary of the history of the ethics discussion. Lawmakers in many countries have determined that compassionate use is acceptable, given the following conditions:

  • The patient has exhausted other comparable treatment options before trying an experimental drug
  • The risks to the patient are deemed no greater than those of not using the experimental drug
  • The patient (or patient’s guardian) gives informed consent — i.e., the patient receives a full explanation of the treatment and associated risks and benefits, and the patient then chooses to go forward with the treatment
  • Compassionate use of the drug does not interfere with completion of clinical trials of the drug which benefit the longer term good of future patients

Visit NYU School of Medicine Working Group on Compassionate Use and Pre-Approval Access to read more about the ethics questions compassionate use stakeholders continue to discuss.

 

__________________________________________________________________

CURe is a registered 501(c)(3) charity recognized by the United States IRS.

Website: www.compassionateusereform.org
Like CURe on Facebook ● Follow CURe on Twitter

Financial—Smaller companies, often the developers of cutting-edge treatments, might be cash strapped and unable to divert funds from clinical trials
Profit—Companies are not allowed to profit from compassionate use
Regulatory—Some companies are concerned that a harmful side effect in a compassionate use case may give government regulators reason to deny approval of the drug
Human Resources & In-House Knowledge—Some smaller companies do not know how to conduct compassionate use and/or cannot afford the additional staff to manage it
Manufacturing—Sometimes a drug company has challenges supplying its clinical trials with the drug and cannot spare drug supplies for compassionate use
Cultural—Some drug companies have not made the decision—yet—that  from the top-down their company will make compassionate use work for the patient when it is medically appropriate and logistically possible
We strongly believe that there are practical win-win solutions to lower or eliminate many of these barriers. Some solutions are already at our fingertips. Others can be built with a willingness to work together. CURe will make that work happen with Solution Hub. Why would drug companies be interested in finding solutions to make compassionate use work?First, drug companies are made up of people, many who want to help other people. Some drug company employees have fought doggedly inside their companies for compassionate use and have been deeply saddened and frustrated when their companies say no. There is a mountain of good will working within the drug development industry, and we want to leverage that for the good of patients and their families.Second, social media and press spotlights have turned up the pressure on drug companies to improve their compassionate use records and to play a leading role in making compassionate use work for patients.A few companies have taken notable steps to improve their compassionate use process. For example, in 2015 Johnson & Johnson announced that they would work with NYU School of Medicine to pilot an external committee to fairly determine which patients should receive compassionate use of a limited supply of one experimental drug. This year the company decided to expand the program to cover all of its experimental medical products. It’s a good start. Is government the problem?Our short answer: No.In the U.S., FDA has a strong compassionate use program that is medically sensible, appropriate for the greater public good, and compassionate towards patients. But until drug companies improve their compassionate use participation, patients and doctors cannot use the FDA program to its full potential.Government still has an important problem-solving role to play. To lower the barriers that drug companies face , we need government participation in building win-win solutions that will work in current and future regulatory environments. Is it ethical to provide compassionate use to patients when the medical treatments are not fully tested and proven effective?The ethics of compassionate use have been a serious discussion since the inception of compassionate use programs.The big question is whether it is ethical to administer experimental drugs to patients before we know if the drugs are effective and before we understand the full set of risks associated with the drug. This article provides a good summary of the history of the ethics discussion. Lawmakers in many countries have determined that compassionate use is acceptable, given the following conditions:
The patient has exhausted other comparable treatment options before trying an experimental drug
The risks to the patient are deemed no greater than those of not using the experimental drug
The patient (or patient’s guardian) gives informed consent — i.e., the patient receives a full explanation of the treatment and associated risks and benefits, and the patient then chooses to go forward with the treatment
Compassionate use of the drug does not interfere with completion of clinical trials of the drug which benefit the longer term good of future patients
Visit NYU School of Medicine Working Group on Compassionate Use and Pre-Approval Access to read more about the ethics questions compassionate use stakeholders continue to discuss. __________________________________________________________________CURe is a registered 501(c)(3) charity recognized by the United States IRS.Website: www.compassionateusereform.orgLike CURe on Facebook ● Follow CURe on Twitter

story:
What if i told you that the rash on your arm could be connected to an emotional or physical event from when you were a child 

 

What if I told you that I understand why your thyroid levels have been off since you had your gallbladder removed

 

What if I gave you the solution to helping your body at any point in life and you no longer viewed health as a mystery  

 

The final gut solution takes a new approach to wellness and healing as it encourages letting go rather than holding on to a strict program and there is no way to possibly mess it up. The final gut solution takes some basic principals of the perfect science of the body combined with everyday life and gives you a toolkit equipped to support your custom healing journey.

For years I have worked with clients who have come to me after their doctors have just shrugged and thrown their hands up at a loss when presented with a condition or reaction in the body that they cant understand. This leaves them feeling anxiety, fear and hopelessness as they don't know who to turn to next. What my program will do is place these mysteries of the body into the formula of how your body really is working. We will start with the digestive system which is the root of all communication in the body. I will give you the information needed to start peeling back the layers of to reveal the answers your body is trying to tell you.

 

t h e   p r o j e c t

My intention with The Final Gut Solution is to take us back to a more primitive understanding of ourselves through connecting the mind and body again. We are so powerful as humans and only use a fraction of the intelligence we are given.

In my late teens I discovered and studied wilderness survival skills and primitive awareness techniques. One of my teachers gave a great analogy of two people lost in the woods, a toddler and a grown man. Intelligence would lead you to believe the survivor is the grown man as he has the most developed mind. Oddly enough the odds of finding the toddler alive 48 hours later are much greater as INSTINCT has guided him to bury in leaves and debris to protect himself from exposure, the same element that has taken the life of the grown man.

This powerful tool of instinct lives in us all and it is truly that GUT feeling that we will ignite together.

With this education and knowledge of rebuilding the gut microbiome and returning the body to a supportive state of homeostasis, there is nothing that will remain a mystery about your own body again.

What is it?

  • 6 Weeks of delivering the content needed to start you on your journey to feeling better than you ever knew you could feel.
  • 3 Private sessions with me spread over a 3 month period for you to have the customized guidance needed to start this journey.
  • A lifelong connection to the online community of people just like you in different stages of healing looking to share experiences and expertise.

 

m y   c l i e n t s  s a y   i t   b e s t 

"Rose has been very helpful with some medical issues that I have been dealing with for a couple years. She taught me how to eat in a way that keeps me full and ensures that my energy levels are high and my issues do not flare up again. I am now aware of what specific types of foods to eat that are beneficial to me. I feel much healthier and through a combination of eating the proper foods and daily exercise I feel like myself again. I am so pleased with the way Rose’s advice has helped me create a healthier lifestyle. I found it fascinating to learn how to group foods together to get the best possible effects and how to choose foods which suited my lifestyle. She provided me with resources and assistance to help me to learn to listen to my body. She was supportive, comforting, funny and knowledgeable. I really can’t say enough amazing things about Rose and what she has done for me! "

"Integrating Rose's nutritional therapy into my wellness experience was one of the best decisions I made to improve my overall heath. Rose is caring, professional, positive, talented and a true expert in her field. I am battling a lifelong rare disease that currently has no cure or treatment available to patients, so I was searching for new innovative approaches in health. Rose meticulously and carefully took the time to learn the intricacies of my disease to devise an individualized curative nutritional plan for my specific needs. She added key nutrients and removed irritant foods which have already helped alleviate and ease some conditions associated with my rare genetic disease. Rose opened my philosophical boundaries by educating me how food communicates with the body. Together, she's helping me utilize food and natural supplements as "Nature's Medicine Cabinet" to address my health. Believing in empowering her clients, Rose is one of the most passionate and inspirational healthcare providers with whom I've worked. Working with Rose has been an absolutely rewarding journey and I have, and will, continue to recommend her with the highest level of confidence to anyone dedicated to improving their health and wellbeing. She gives me hope and helped me discover the power to influence the direction of my health with a personalized natural whole approach."

 

a b o u t   m e

My focus is working with digestive issues that are sourced from an emotional holding and working with them to gracefully unlock these root issues. The manifestations of this can appear as weight gain, IBS, Chronic yeast/ bacterial infections, Ulcers, Depression, Fatigue, Acne, MS, Crohn's, etc. I believe we are all on very different healing journeys and customizing a solution is the only way to find full resolution. 

I have been on an amazing journey for the past 20 years leading up to my current position as a Holistic Health Practitioner, having studied health coaching at the The Institute for Integrative Nutrition. My experience first began with a natural desire to help people as well as heal myself from chronic IBS and Stress Ulcers. As a young adult I began studying Native American philosophy with a focus on awareness and dynamic meditation. This lead to a great knowledge and appreciation for nature and all it provides for us. Feeling like there was more I could be doing I then discovered Body Psychotherapy, finally a practical application to everything I believed in the process of self healing. Through this process of working through trapped emotions within the body I eliminated digestive issues completely from my life, never to return. I also became a Massage Therapist where I combined my awareness and body working skills to help people on their personal healing journey. Still I felt I needed the complete mind body spirit application which is what brought me to create the Final Gut Solution. Now I am able to help people in all aspects of their life to discover how to live as their optimal self.

 

r i s k s   a n d   c h a l l e n g e s 

The funds I am asking for will be most importantly be used to set up this project correctly from a legal perspective. The nature of of my discussions and topics will need to stay within my scope of practice as a health practitioner and I will be consulting legal counsel to review and advise on this topic. 


In addition, I will be setting this up as a completely new company from my previous Present Wellness and startup costs will include video production, CPA consulting fees and social media marketing expenses for the first 6 months.

story:
Greetings and salutations to all my special friends and family!

I am proud to announce I will be starting my own business in massage therapy, spa therapies and body/mind somatic therapies. I am taking an integrative approach toward healing the body, mind and spirit. Of course, I am super excited and would like to pass on the beauty of my beginnings to all of you.

I have been given a wonderful opportunity to open up a space which includes two small treatment rooms and a cozy waiting room. It is located in the upstairs area of the Daniel Jordan Salon in the Encino Town Center on Ventura Boulevard. I have been lucky enough to be given a discounted rent rate for three months, in order to have time to build my business. However, to get properly situated and launched comfortably, I will need a stable starting point of at least $5000.

Rather than seeking an angel investor, which would be time-consuming and potentially difficult, my hope is to gather the support of my friends and family by bringing you on-board as allies and, potentially, as clients. I am reaching out for help with financially facilitating this endeavor.

I have created the perfect "you scratch my back, I'll rub yours" proposal! In exchange for a pre-paid purchase of $65, you will receive any 60-minute treatment of your choice; from a general deep tissue massage to a somatic bodywork session or an integrative wellness coaching session, so you can start the new year right! Please consider treating yourself and helping me earn the start-up capital I need to build this business. Together we will see something wonderful happen with it. 

I have the basic amenities covered right now and can start seeing clients as soon as tomorrow. I still need to pay for business licensing and permits, some furniture, massage linens and towels, plus minor advertising and web development. 

Get a service for yourself, a friend or family member, or…get one for me! (I'm certainly going to need one after this undertaking, working 12 hours a day and 7 days a week.)

Thank you so much for taking the time to consider my proposal! There's nothing more lovely than my knowing I've got a powerhouse of allies behind me.
See you on 'the table'!
